name: Maren
Morris:
Girl
review
–
country
or
pop,

stuck
in
the
middle
Music
The
Guardian
content:
Any artist who makes their name subverting norms faces a challenge on album two: you can’t subvert the same norm twice, but step off the soapbox and you’ll be accused of growing toothless. Critics hailed Maren Morris’s 2016 debut, Hero, for her repudiation of country tropes, and for convincingly aligning Nashville craft with pop scale. But then she found commercial success with The Middle, a thrillingly weird post-EDM collaboration with producer Zedd that seemed to suggest country as her stopover on the way to the mainstream.





















 


  

 


  Facebook 
 


  Twitter 
 


  Pinterest 





  Maren Morris: Girl album artwork


Girl, Morris’s second album, ultimately traffics in neither gutsy grandstanding nor Vegas-adjacent pop. Morris’s co-writers remain blue-chip Nashville, among them Ryan Hurd, whom she married last year. Their relationship underpins Girl, represented as a romance for the ages (Great Ones), salvation (Gold Love) and an enduring sugar rush (the self-explanatory Make Out With Me). But for all the biographical sincerity, Morris’s songs about unfettered good times feel unconvincing.Morris has a compellingly hardbitten voice that’s wasted on the boozy camaraderie of All My Favourite People and the blown-out Flavour, not to mention the twee, plinky-plonky A Song for Everything, which strings together nostalgic tropes to push cheap emotional buttons. “My first lighter up was back when Coldplay still played clubs,” Morris sings, which seems unlikely given that she was about nine then. None of them are strong enough to tower over their flaws.Also disappointing is Common, featuring Brandi Carlile, a gothic plea for unity that feels feeble next to Morris’s brazen (for a country star) real-life proclamations on gun control. It’s stranger still because the best songs on Girl dwell on friction. “What’s left of my halo’s black / Lucky for me, your kind of heaven’s been to hell and back,” she sings on To Hell & Back, a bittersweet, pragmatic love song that swells between anxiety and mellow reassurance, while The Bones draws out the inherent ruefulness in her voice.This relative disappointment recalls Kacey Musgraves following the sparky Same Trailer, Different Park with the underwhelming Pageant Material. But then, Musgraves’s next move was the psychedelic Golden Hour, hailed by many as 2018’s best album. Hopefully the same uptick in inspiration befalls Morris.
